Award.AbstractNarration: Mosco<br/>DMS-0807840<br/><br/> The investigator and his colleagues study mathematical<br/>problems with large surfaces and small volumes that arise in<br/>physics (e.g., highly fragmented electrical conductors, high<br/>voltage electric discharges, electrolytic deposition,<br/>diffusion-limited aggregation), chemistry (catalytic converters,<br/>surface chemistry), biology (cell membranes, vascular systems),<br/>engineering (hydraulic fracturing in oil wells, thin ramified<br/>fibers, elastic thin bodies, towers and bridges in open space). <br/>In all these problems a lower-dimensional physical body -- the<br/>"surface" -- intrudes and interacts with a full dimensional<br/>surrounding body -- the "volume." The volume is small, the<br/>surface is large, possibly fractal and with infinite area. In<br/>this project, the mathematics of fractal structures in space is<br/>focused on two fundamental issues: 1) second order transmission<br/>conditions for second order operators; 2) singular homogenization<br/>with fractal terms. New tools of analysis are developed, like<br/>Hoelder metrics and measure-valued Lagrangeans. Finite element<br/>numerical approximations provide the quantitative and flexible<br/>setting required by prospective applications such as those<br/>mentioned above. The principal investigator and his colleagues<br/>develop new mathematics aimed at meeting the challenges and<br/>taking advantage of the new technologies of the time. <br/><br/> The mathematics developed in this project is motivated by,<br/>and oriented to, the study of applied problems of unusual type,<br/>occurring in the materials sciences and manufacturing,<br/>nanotechnology, biotechnology, and the environmental sciences. <br/>The unusual feature of these problems consists in the presence<br/>and interaction, within the same system, of two physical<br/>phenomena, one confined in a "small volume," the second unfolding<br/>itself on a "large surface." Nanotechnology can produce very<br/>fine fractal surfaces that can be assembled to form composite<br/>materials with enhanced internal surface effects (catalytic<br/>devices, absorbers, surface chemistry, radiators and similar). <br/>Environment-driven fractal networks can support irrigation of<br/>large surfaces with scarce fluid volume (as in vascular and<br/>biological systems). Interlaced thin fibers and fractal thin<br/>structures can tune wave propagation in space. Despite their<br/>complexity, these applications hinge on an unusual volume vs.<br/>surface relation of the kind mentioned before. The project<br/>involves young researchers and students -- with attention to<br/>underrepresented minorities -- who receive a broad, flexible<br/>training that provides access to science and technology as well<br/>to professional activities outside academic institutions.
